I have a real hard time watching this because of my fear of heights, but I made myself do it anyway and just cringed when you got close to the edge.😬 That being said, I'm pretty well convinced that ancient man did NOT build this place without some outside help. There's no way they could have stacked those huge boulders with tolerances that you couldn't even slip a sheet of paper between. Just the machining process of the building blocks alone would have taken hundreds.. no, thousands of years to complete by hand. That doesn't even take into account all the complex terraces that they are built on. This place is amazing, even though I'd never be able to walk it in person. Definitely some next level architecture (literally!). 👽😉👍 Thanks for the tour Destin!😁

The problem with in ear binaural mics is they sit quite far out from the ear. It lessens the impact that the pinna has on the recorded audio. The pinna shape is crucial in your localisation of sound especially vertically as the time and frequency difference between the two ears is the same if the sound is directly above, in front, below or behind you. If you use a dummy head for example the neumann binaural setup, the mics are placed back inside the ear canal and therefore the pressure differences and pinna affect the sound too making for a far more realistic experience. Would be cool if you could get hold of one for a future video. As an audio engineer I find this stuff fascinating!

Proper binaural sound would actually require the microphones to be 'inside' your ears. Your setup in this video is providing fairly realistic stereo sound (direction), but doesn't reproduce distance (or height offset), or reproduce the sensation of sounds coming from the rear. In order to accomplish that, the sound has to be influenced by the cartilage that makes up the outer ear.

This type of audio recording is really cool but due to the mics being on either side of the head you find this spacial gap when listening   If you were to try out a mid/side set up you would find it to be a lot more natural as it is a balance of a centre mic and a stereo pair - the stereo pair can have the level adjusted to produce either a super wide sound or blended with the centre mic which gives the audio more focus and reality... go try it out and thanks for all the great films.

This recording technique filters different frequencies depending on where the sound is coming from, just about the same way your head does. So when you listen to such recordings with the left and right channels against your left and right ears your brain can't tell the difference between recording and a sound being emitted in the same position relative to you; sounds like you're really there, or that the sources of the sound are in the room with you.
But only works with headphones.

Nah, now wait a minute. I've gotten a bunch of replies saying surround sound/stereo sound is the same as binaural. Now that's just not true. At 0:19 the guy says "Binaural mics take into account that you have a head, which stereo mics do not." Stereo mics are "2D" meaning that you can tell if a sound is coming from left or right (maybe front and back, I don't know). Binaurals are "3D" meaning you can tell how far it is, and up and down. watch?v=IUDTlvagjJA&list=FLhTBBXbLy7cRLbHcn_962JA&index=4

they do have it...
its called surround sound

They tried it with games back in the 90's. The problem was that you had to wear headphones, so end users usually didn't "get" it. Also, recording was an issue. A video is simple, use two mics, spaced properly apart with a special filter and go. Video games use sounds that can come from any direction, at any given time. How to take a single sound, and make that happen? Processing at run time was processor prohibitive, and tons of audio storage used lots of space...

Your brain determines direction of the origin of a sound by comparing its phase and amplitude at each ear. A binaural mic system works by recording the exact sound that would enter your ear if you were there, therefore the speaker used for playback must be in the same position relative to the listener's ear as the mic was be for recording, hence headphones. They also provide acoustic isolation between the ears. Using loudspeakers would add further phase/crosstalk, nulling the effect.

The fisheye is a good thing and a bad thing. Normally it is a bad thing, but to make it a good thing raise it to full 1080hd and lean forward until the video fills your peripheral vision.
